questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:
A mineral hydrate (MH) is an ionic compound that has associated H2O molecules. Dehydration (removal of all H2O) of an MH produces its anhydrous salt (an ionic com­pound that has no associated H2O molecules), which may differ in color from the MH. Table 1 shows, for each of 4 MHs, the chemical formula of one formula unit of the MH, its color, and the color of its anhydrous salt.



Figure 1 shows the mass of a sample that was con­verted from chalcanthite to CuSO4 as its temperature was increased from 0°C to 350°C.



Table 2 shows the solubility in H2O of each anhydrous salt at 20°C, 40°C, 60°C, and 80°C.
questions.question: 1. According to Table 2, which of the following graphs best shows, for each of the 4 anhydrous salts, the solubility in H2O at 80°C ?

questions.question: 2. According to Table 2, as temperature increases from 20°C through 80°C, the solubility in H2O of CoSO4  and the solubility in H2O of FeSO4 :

questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:
A mineral hydrate (MH) is an ionic compound that has associated H2O molecules. Dehydration (removal of all H2O) of an MH produces its anhydrous salt (an ionic com­pound that has no associated H2O molecules), which may differ in color from the MH. Table 1 shows, for each of 4 MHs, the chemical formula of one formula unit of the MH, its color, and the color of its anhydrous salt.



Figure 1 shows the mass of a sample that was con­verted from chalcanthite to CuSO4 as its temperature was increased from 0°C to 350°C.



Table 2 shows the solubility in H2O of each anhydrous salt at 20°C, 40°C, 60°C, and 80°C.
questions.question: 6. A student claimed that 50 g of CuSO4 will dissolve in 300 g of H2O at 20°C. Does Table 2 support this claim?

choices.A: No; only 20 g of CuSO4 will dissolve.
choices.B: No; only 40 g of CuSO4 will dissolve.
choices.C: Yes; up to 60 g of CuSO4 will dissolve.
choices.D: Yes; up to 80 g of CuSO4 will dissolve.

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:
During a demonstration, a teacher placed 20 mL of water , 10 mL of isopropyl alcohol (IPA), and 1 drop of blue food coloring into a test tube, capped the test tube, and inverted it 6 times. Next, she added 7 g of ammonium sulfate (AS), an ionic solid, to the test tube, capped the test tube, and vigorously shook it for 10 sec. Then, over the 15 sec period immediately following the shaking, the mix­ture in the test tube completely separated into 2 distinct liquid layers (see figure).



The teacher asked each of 4 students to provide an explanation for what occurred in the test tube over the 15 sec period.

Student 1
Over the 15 sec, the mixture separated into 2 layers because IPA is denser than water. The water layer was on top, and the IPA layer was on the bottom. The AS dissolved in the IPA only, because AS breaks apart into neutral mole­cules when dissolved in IPA. Blue food coloring is polar, so it dissolved in the water only.

Student 2
Over the 15 sec, the mixture separated into 2 layers because water is denser than IPA. The IPA layer was on top, and the water layer was on the bottom. The AS dis­solved in the water only, because AS breaks apart into neu­tral molecules when dissolved in water. Blue food coloring is polar, so it dissolved in the IPA only.

Student 3
Over the 15 sec, the mixture separated into 2 layers because the AS dissolved in the IPA only, causing the den­sity of the IPA layer to increase . The water layer was on top, and the IPA layer was on the bottom. The AS dissolved m the IPA only, because AS breaks apart into ions when dissolved in IPA. Blue food coloring is polar, so it dis­solved in the water only.

Student 4
Over the 15 sec, the mixture separated into 2 layers because the AS dissolved in the water only, causing the density of the water layer to increase. The IPA layer was on top, and the water layer was on the bottom. The AS dis­solved in the water only, because AS breaks apart into ions when dissolved in water. Blue food coloring is polar, so it dissolved in the IPA only.
questions.question: 7. Which of Students 1 and 2, if either, claimed that water is denser than IPA ?

questions.article:

questions.question: 8. Suppose that 20 mL of water and 20 mL of IPA are poured into a beaker, mixed, and then allowed to settle. Based on Student 2's explanation, the resulting con­tents of the beaker would best be represented by which of the following diagrams?

questions.question: 9. Consider the diagram below.The locations of the water, IPA, dissolved blue food coloring, and dissolved AS shown in the diagram are consistent with the explanation(s) given by which of the students?

questions.question: 10. Which students, if any, would be likely to agree that after the 2 layers completely separated, the blue food coloring and the AS were both dissolved in the same layer?

questions.question: 11. Based on the figure, 5 sec after the shaking, would the contents of the test tube have been better classified as a heterogeneous mixture or a homogeneous mixture ?

choices.A: Heterogeneous, because the contents of the test tube varied in composition from one region to another .
choices.B: Heterogeneous, because the contents of the test tube were uniform in composition throughout.
choices.C: Homogeneous, because the contents of the test tube varied in composition from one region to another .
choices.D: Homogeneous, because the contents of the  test tube were uniform in composition throughout.

questions.question: 13. The chemical formula of AS is (NH4)2SO4. Based on Student 3's explanation, which of the following chemical equations best represents a process that only occurred in the IPA?

questions.title: Passage Ill
questions.article:
A consumer safety laboratory conducted 3 studies of vehicle braking performance under various conditions.


Study 1
Each of 3 identical vehicles was equipped with a dif­ferent braking system (System X, System Y, or System Z). Each vehicle was subjected to 10 trials on a dry road and 10 trials on a wet road. In each trial, the following steps were performed:

1. The vehicle was accelerated to 30 m/sec.

2. The braking system was fully engaged, and the vehicle's stopping distance, S (the distance required for the vehi­cle to come to a stop), was measured.

3. The vehicle's braking deceleration, B (the average rate at which the vehicle's speed decreased while the braking system was engaged), was calculated using the equation

The results of each set of 10 trials were then averaged to obtain an average S (in m) and an average B (in m/sec2) for each braking system on each type of road. Table 1 shows the results.



Study 2
 Three hundred kilograms of cargo was placed into each of the vehicles that were tested in Study 1, and the procedures of Study 1 were repeated. Table 2 shows the results.




Study 3
System X was installed in a compact car, a sedan, a minivan, and a truck. The procedures for determining aver­age S in Study 1 were then repeated for each vehicle, with­out cargo, on both the dry and wet roads (see Figure 1).
questions.question: 14. Which of the following statements about the design of the 3 studies is consistent with their descriptions?

choices.A: Study 1 was the only study in which more than 3 vehicles were involved
choices.B: Study 2 was the only study in which cargo was involved.
choices.C: Studies 1 and 3 were the only 2 studies in which vehicles were tested on both road types.
choices.D: Studies 2 and 3 were the only 2 studies in which System Z was not tested.

The results of each set of 10 trials were then averaged to obtain an average S (in m) and an average B (in m/sec2) for each braking system on each type of road. Table 1 shows the results.



Study 2
 Three hundred kilograms of cargo was placed into each of the vehicles that were tested in Study 1, and the procedures of Study 1 were repeated. Table 2 shows the results.




Study 3

questions.question: 15. Any braking system that resulted in an average S that was greater than 50.0 m was designated as "unsafe" by the researchers at the laboratory. Based on the  results of Studies 1 and 2, which system(s) was(were) most likely designated as "unsafe" under at least 1 set of conditions?

questions.question: 16. The table below gives the masses of the vehicles tested in Study 3.For a given road type, as vehicle mass increased, the average S:

choices.D: varied, but with no general trend.

questions.question: 17. Consider the set of 10 trials in Study 2 in which the vehicle equipped with System Y was tested on the dry road. Which of the following statements about the vehicle's 10 stopping distances is most likely correct?

choices.A: All 10 distances were less than 60.7 m
choices.B: All 10 distances were equal to 60.7 m
choices.C: All 10 distances were greater than 60.7 m
choices.D: Some of the distances were less than 60.7 m, and some of the distances were greater than 60. 7 m.

questions.question: 18. Suppose that in Study 3, a fifth vehicle had been tested on the dry road, and its average B was determined  to be 7.7 m/. Based on the results of Study 1, the average S for this vehicle on the dry road would most likely have been closest to the average S in Study 3 for which other type of vehicle on the dry road?

questions.question: 19. According to the results of Studies 1 and 2, compared with the trials performed on the dry road, the trials per­ formed on the wet road resulted in:

choices.A: greater average stopping distances and greater average braking decelerations.
choices.B: greater average stopping distances and lesser aver­age braking decelerations.
choices.C: lesser average stopping distances and greater aver­age braking decelerations.
choices.D: lesser average stopping distances and lesser aver­age braking decelerations.

2. The braking system was fully engaged, and the vehicle's stopping distance, S (the distance required for the vehi­cle to come to a stop), was measured.

3. The vehicle's braking deceleration, B (the average rate at which the vehicle's speed decreased while the braking system was engaged), was calculated using the equation

The results of each set of 10 trials were then averaged to obtain an average S (in m) and an average B (in m/sec2) for each braking system on each type of road. Table 1 shows the results.



Study 2
 Three hundred kilograms of cargo was placed into each of the vehicles that were tested in Study 1, and the procedures of Study 1 were repeated. Table 2 shows the results.




Study 3
System X was installed in a compact car, a sedan, a minivan, and a truck. The procedures for determining aver­age S in Study 1 were then repeated for each vehicle, with­out cargo, on both the dry and wet roads (see Figure 1).
questions.question: 20. In a new set of 10 trials performed on the dry road, the vehicle with System Z was accelerated to  60 m/sec with no cargo. To calculate B, the following equation was used:The average B for this set of trials was 10.0 . Was the average S more likely less than 45.1 m or greater than 45.1 m ?

choices.A: Less; a vehicle decelerating at the same  rate from a lower speed requires less distance to come to a stop.
choices.B: Less; a vehicle decelerating  at the same rate from a higher speed requires less distance to come to a stop.
choices.C: Greater; a vehicle decelerating at the same rate from a lower speed requires more distance to come to a stop.
choices.D: Greater; a vehicle decelerating at the same rate from a higher speed requires more distance to come to a stop.

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
Scientists studied the speed of the wind and the size of sand grains at 4 sites on a sand dune (see diagram). At each site, 4 anemometers (devices for measuring wind speed) were attached to a vertical pole at different heights above the ground , and a sand trap was placed at the base of the pole. Each trap could collect only windblown sand grains having diameters from 0.0625 mm to 0.5 mm.



Study
Over a particular 45 min period, wind speed was mea­sured multiple times by each anemometer and sand was collected at all 4 sites

The average wind speed at each anemometer for the 45 min period was calculated . Then each average wind speed was converted to a relative wind speed. (The relative wind speed at an anemometer equaled the average wind speed at the anemometer divided by the average wind speed 12.0 m above the ground at the dune crest site for the same period.) The results are shown in Figure 1.


The mass of the sand collected at each site was mea­sured. Then the sand from each site was sifted through a stack of 12 screens to separate the grains into 13 portions according to diameter. (Each screen had uniform openings of a smaller diameter than the openings in the screen above.) The percent of the sand's mass from grains making up each of the 13 portions was determined (see Figure 2).
questions.question: 21. According to Figure 1, at the interdune site , as anemometer height above the ground increased, rela­tive wind speed:

questions.question: 22. According to Figure 2, sand grains making up which 2 adjacent portions accounted for more than half of the total mass of the collected sand from the dune crest site?

questions.question: 27. The medium sand grains collected in the study were those that made up Portions 1-4, and the very fine sand grains collected in the study were those that made up Portions 10-13. According to Figure 2, from  site  to site downwind, how did the total percent by mass of the medium sand grains change, and how did the total percent by mass of the very fine sand grains change?

choices.A: medium sand grains:  decrease ;           very fine sand grains: increase
choices.B: medium sand grains:  increase ;           very fine sand grains: decrease
choices.C: medium sand grains:  increase ;           very fine sand grains: increase
choices.D: medium sand grains:  decrease ;           very fine sand grains: decrease

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article:
As a person ages, the levels of antioxidants—com­pounds that reduce the number of cell-damaging reactive oxygen molecules (ROM) — may decrease in the body. Tea extracts are a dietary source of antioxidants .

Table 1 shows the percent by mass of each of the 4 major antioxidants (A1-A4) present in 5 tea extracts (T1-T5).


Researchers studied the ability of A1-A4 and of T1-T5 to reduce the number of ROM.


Study 1
Solutions having the same concentration of ROM and various concentrations of A1, A2, A3, or A4 were incubated, each in a separate test tube at 25°C for 30 min. The compound NBT was then added to each tube, where it reacted with all the remaining ROM to form the blue dye formazan. Figure 1 shows, for A1-A4, how the for­mazan concentration varied with the initial antioxidant concentration.



Study 2
Elderly male rats received the same daily dose of T1, T2, T3, T4, or T5, or water only, for 4 weeks. A 1 mg sample of heart tissue was then collected from each rat.
Each sample was placed in a separate test tube con­taining 10 mL of a solution of the compound TBA. Each tube was incubated at 100°C for 1 hr to allow the TBA to react with all the malondialdehyde (a product of ROM cell damage) in the sample to form a pink dye. The concentra­tion of pink dye was measured to determine the malondialdehyde concentration and, thus, the extent of ROM cell damage in the sample.

Figure 2 shows the average malondialdehyde concen­tration of the solutions resulting from each treatment.
questions.question: 28. Based on the results of Study 1, at an initial antioxi­dant concentration of 5.0 mg/L, the solution containing which antioxidant had the lowest dye concentration ?

questions.question: 29. If a trial had been done in Study 1 at an initial A3 con­centration of 4.0 mg/L, the formazan concentration would most likely have been closest to which of the following?

questions.question: 31. Consider the results of the trials in Study 1 for the 4 antioxidants at any given initial antioxidant concen­tration. For which of the following reasons could these results be validly compared? The solutions in the test tubes had:

choices.A: the same initial concentration of malondialdehyde.
choices.C: the same initial concentration of ROM.

questions.question: 33. Suppose that in a new study the procedures of Study 2 are repeated except that the rats receive only 50% of the daily dose of each tea extract that the rats received in Study 2. Would the malondialdehyde concentration measured for T1 more likely be higher or lower than the value for T1 shown in Figure 2 ?

choices.A: Higher, because fewer ROM  would  be  eliminated.
choices.B: Higher, because  more ROM  would  be eliminated.
choices.C: Lower, because fewer ROM would be eliminated.
choices.D: Lower, because more ROM would be eliminated.

questions.question: 34. In Study 1, each test tube was incubated for 30 min to allow sufficient time for the ROM to react with the:

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article: In the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the function of meiosis is to divide a diploid cell into 4 haploid cells called spores. During meiosis, the 2 copies of a chromosome, or homologs, undergo DNA replication (when each homolog becomes a linked pair of sister chromatids) followed by 2 rounds of chromosome segregation (separation into different cells) called Meiosis I and Meiosis II. The figure shows the homologs of a particular chromosome during meiosis in a wild-type S. cerevisiae strain and also in 2 mutant S. cerevisiae strains (Mutant A and Mutant B) each having a different mutation that affects meiosis.
questions.question: 35. According to the figure, how many cells are directly produced by Meiosis I in the Mutant A S. cerevisiae strain, and how many cells are directly produced by Meiosis I in the Mutant B S. cerevisiae strain?

choices.A: Mutant A strain: 1;           Mutant B strain: 1
choices.B: Mutant A strain: 1;           Mutant B strain: 2
choices.C: Mutant A strain: 2;           Mutant B strain: 1
choices.D: Mutant A strain: 4;           Mutant B strain: 2

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article: In the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the function of meiosis is to divide a diploid cell into 4 haploid cells called spores. During meiosis, the 2 copies of a chromosome, or homologs, undergo DNA replication (when each homolog becomes a linked pair of sister chromatids) followed by 2 rounds of chromosome segregation (separation into different cells) called Meiosis I and Meiosis II. The figure shows the homologs of a particular chromosome during meiosis in a wild-type S. cerevisiae strain and also in 2 mutant S. cerevisiae strains (Mutant A and Mutant B) each having a different mutation that affects meiosis.
questions.question: 36. According to the figure, does meiosis in the Mutant B S. cerevisiae strain produce as many spores as does meiosis in a wild-type S. cerevisiae strain?

choices.A: No; 2 Mutant B S. cerevisiae spores are produced.
choices.B: No; 4 Mutant B S. cerevisiae spores are produced.
choices.C: Yes; 2 Mutant B S. cerevisiae spores are produced.
choices.D: Yes; 4 Mutant B S. cerevisiae spores are produced.

questions.question: 37. Suppose that 10 chromosomes were found in each of the spores of another species of yeast, Species X. Assuming that there were no mutations that affected the formation of the spores, what is the diploid number of chromosomes of Species X ?

choices.C: Both  the Mutant  A strain and the Mutant  B strain
choices.D: Neither the Mutant A strain nor the Mutant B strain

questions.question: 39. The depiction of meiosis in the figure for which of the three S. cerevisiae strains, if any, is consistent with the statement "DNA replication occurs between Meiosis  I and Meiosis II" ?

choices.D: None of the strains; DNA replication occurs before Meiosis I.

questions.title: Passage VI

questions.question: 40. Based on the figure, for a wild- type S. cerevisiae strain, the total mass of DNA per cell is greatest at a time between the:

choices.A: end of interphase and the start of DNA replication.
choices.B: end of DNA replication and the start of Meiosis I.
choices.C: end of Meiosis I and the start of Meiosis II.
choices.D: end of Meiosis II and the start of interphase.
